entry.title: SAP BNAC as AAS Server: Driving Interoperability and Efficiency in Digital Twin Collaboration
entry.content:
SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration  (BNAC) is taking a major leap forward in enabling standardized, interoperable digital twin ecosystems. With its latest innovation, SAP BNAC now acts as an Asset Administration Shell (AAS) Server, supporting AAS APIs and delivering seamless integration across the value chain. This capability empowers OEMs, operators, and suppliers to exchange asset data efficiently, automate processes, and prepare for compliance with initiatives like the Digital Product Passport (DPP).

Why AAS Matters

The Asset Administration Shell (IEC 63278) is the Industry 4.0 standard for representing a digital twin of an asset—whether a component, machine, or plant. It structures master data, documentation, and operational data into Submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation) and exposes them via standardized APIs. This eliminates custom integrations and ensures consistent semantics across partners.

By supporting AAS APIs, SAP BNAC becomes a native AAS Server in your digital twin landscape. This means:

  • Consume, create, and manage AAS content directly in SAP BNAC
  • Connect suppliers, OEMs, and operators using industry standards
  • Enable end-to-end collaboration without manual data translation

What’s New: SAP BNAC as AAS Server

With AAS API support, SAP BNAC offers:

  • Standardized AAS onboarding: Suppliers upload AAS and Submodels* via APIs.
  • Automated mapping: AAS elements are translated into SAP business objects (Model, Equipment, Documents).
  • Interoperability at scale: Connect with external AAS systems and ecosystems like Factory-X.

Note (*): Supported submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation)

Key Use Cases

1) Streamlined Onboarding of Asset Data into Business Systems (import of AAS via AAS API)

Traditionally, AAS data was imported via file-based methods (read my previous article if you want to learn more on how SAP BNAC already support AASX import). Now, SAP BNAC enables API-based AAS import, streamlining collaboration between manufacturers and system integrators.

How it works:

  • A system integrator retrieves AAS and Submodels from suppliers via APIs to SAP BNAC as AAS Server.
  • SAP BNAC automatically creates corresponding business objects:
    • Model (AAS Type)
    • Equipment (AAS Instance)
    • Documents
  • Data syncs with SAP ERP for processes like purchase orders (**).

Note (**): SAP BNAC and SAP ERP requires initial configuration (mapping BNAC objects to existing ERP classes and characteristics)

Business Value:

  • Faster onboarding of component data (e.g., motors, controllers, valves).
  • Reduced manual effort and error-prone mapping.
  • Improved collaboration during asset definition.

2) End-to-End ERP–AAS Integration

Beyond import, SAP BNAC supports AAS export via AAS APIs, enabling organizations to share standardized digital twins derived from SAP ERP data.

How it works:

  • Materials and Equipment from SAP ERP are replicated in SAP BNAC.
  • Classified using Templates aligned with AAS Submodels (Digital Nameplate).
  • Exposed via AAS APIs for third-party systems.

Note: additional configuration and mapping between SAP ERP and SAP BNAC needed. Also, AAS and Submodels metadata (e.g., AAS id) must be added in SAP BNAC.

Business Value:

  • Out-of-the-box interoperability: AAS and Submodels like Digital Nameplate are derived out of ERP.
  • Enhanced transparency across the asset lifecycle.
  • Easier integration with 3rd party systems via AAS APIs.

Why This Matters for OEMs and Operators

  • Efficiency without custom integrations: Standards-based APIs reduce complexity and cost as well as make it easier to bring asset data into your business processes.
  • Rich collaboration: Access technical data, certificates, manuals, and more through AAS Submodels.
  • Future-proof: Prepare for DPP and Industry 4.0 ecosystems.

Getting Started

Explore:

  • SAP BNAC Product Documentation
  • AAS API Overview

Takeaways

SAP BNAC as AAS Server is more than a technical enhancement—it’s a strategic enabler for digital twin collaboration. By leveraging AAS standards, businesses can:

  • Automate asset data creation.
  • Accelerate supplier onboarding.
  • Ensure compliance and interoperability.
  • Unlock new value streams through richer networks and standardized data exchange.

What is next

What is next - our journey has just started. Our plan is support additional Submodels and ensure that you will be compliant with DPP and DPB. Got curious? Please reach out to us and be part of this journey!

entry.title: Converting Property Graphs to Knowledge Graphs in SAP HANA Cloud: A Simple Guide
entry.content:
Graphs are becoming a core part of how businesses understand their data. In SAP HANA Cloud, we already support strong property graph capabilities through the property graph engine, and a rich RDF/Knowledge Graph model through the knowledge graph engine. Until now, these two worlds lived separately.

 With our new built-in graph procedure, we make it possible to turn a property graph into a knowledge graph (RDF) in one step. This gives customers the best of both worlds: the flexibility of property graphs and the semantic richness of RDF. This blog walks through the idea in simple terms and shows how it works behind the scenes.

Before we jump into details, let’s understand why we would want to convert a property graph to a knowledge graph:

Customers often start with a property graph because it is easy to model, easy to modify, and great for traversal and analytics.
Over time, they want additional capabilities like:

  • a standardized representation of entities
  • richer semantic modeling
  • SPARQL querying
  • interoperability with external tools
  • grounding their data for AI, LLMs, and RAG pipelines

Knowledge graphs shine here. By converting property graphs to the RDF format, teams can keep using their familiar structure while unlocking a wider ecosystem.

The new built-in procedure

SAP HANA Cloud introduces a simple, built-in procedure from its QRC4 2025 release: RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE. This procedure converts a property graph workspace into an RDF graph (knowledge graph).
It copies the graph data, but keeps the models independent. This means updates to one don’t automatically reflect in the other.

A simple supply chain graph example

To make this more tangible, let’s walk through a small but realistic example.

Imagine a supply chain graph with three main tables:

  • Suppliers - Each supplier has attributes like name, country, and risk level.
  • Materials - Materials represent the goods being supplied.
  • Shipments - Shipments connect suppliers to materials and carry business context such as shipment status and delay days.

In SAP HANA Cloud, we will first model this as a property graph workspace.

  • Suppliers and materials are vertex tables
  • Shipments are an edge table connecting suppliers to materials
  • Shipment specific attributes remain attached to the edge

This structure is very natural for operational and analytical use cases. You can easily answer questions like:

  • Which suppliers provide a given material?
  • Which suppliers are associated with delayed shipments?
  • How does risk propagate through the supply network?

Creating the property graph

At the data level, the graph is built on top of relational tables. Suppliers and materials are modeled as vertex tables, while shipments act as the edge table connecting them. Once the tables are defined, a graph workspace ties everything together:

Step 1: Let’s begin with creating plain relational tables.

Suppliers

CREATE SCHEMA SCM;
SET SCHEMA SCM;
CREATE TABLE SCM.SUPPLIERS (
  SUPPLIERID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  NAME       NVARCHAR(100),
  COUNTRY    NVARCHAR(50),
  RISKLEVEL  NVARCHAR(20)
);

Materials

CREATE TABLE SCM.MATERIALS (
  MATERIALID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  NAME       NVARCHAR(100)
);

Shipments (relationship data)

CREATE TABLE SCM.SHIPMENTS (
  SHIPMENTID NVARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY,
  SUPPLIER   NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
  MATERIAL   NVARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
  STATUS     NVARCHAR(20),
  DELAYDAYS  INTEGER
);

Step 2: Insert sample data in the created tables

--Suppliers
INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S1', 'Alpha Metals', 'China', 'High');

INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S2', 'Nordic Steel', 'Sweden', 'Low');

INSERT INTO SCM.SUPPLIERS (SupplierID, Name, Country, RiskLevel)
VALUES ('S3', 'TerraChem', 'Brazil', 'Medium');

--Materials
INSERT INTO SCM.MATERIALS (MaterialID, Name)
VALUES ('M1', 'Steel Rods');

INSERT INTO SCM.MATERIALS (MaterialID, Name)
VALUES ('M2', 'Copper Wire');

--Shipments
INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH1', 'S1', 'M1', 'Delayed', 12);

INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH2', 'S2', 'M1', 'OnTime', 0);

INSERT INTO SCM.SHIPMENTS (ShipmentID, Supplier, Material, Status, DelayDays)
VALUES ('SH3', 'S3', 'M2', 'Delayed', 5);

At this point, the data is still relational.

Step 3: Create a property graph workspace

Now we turn the above tables into a graph workspace - SUPPLY_GRAPH.

CREATE GRAPH WORKSPACE SCM.SUPPLY_GRAPH
  VERTEX TABLE SCM.SUPPLIERS
    KEY SUPPLIERID
  VERTEX TABLE SCM.MATERIALS
    KEY MATERIALID
  EDGE TABLE SCM.SHIPMENTS
    KEY SHIPMENTID
    SOURCE SUPPLIER REFERENCES SCM.SUPPLIERS
    TARGET MATERIAL REFERENCES SCM.MATERIALS;

What this gives us:

  • Vertices
    • Suppliers with properties like name, country, risk level
    • Materials with their attributes
  • Edges
    • Shipments connecting suppliers to materials
    • Edge properties such as status and delay days

This graph is optimized for traversal and graph algorithms.

Step 4: What’s new in QRC4 2025 - Property Graph (PG) to Knowledge Graph (KG) conversion

This is where the new functionality - RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE  comes in.  It converts an existing graph workspace into an RDF knowledge graph - 'scmkg'.

The conversion call :

CALL RDF_GRAPH_FROM_GRAPH_WORKSPACE(
    GRAPH_WORKSPACE_SCHEMA_NAME => 'SCM',
    GRAPH_WORKSPACE_NAME        => 'SUPPLY_GRAPH',
    TARGET_GRAPH_URI            => '<scmkg>',
    MAPPING_MODE                => 'AUTO',
    MAPPING_OUT                 => ?
);

Step 5: How the conversion works (in simple terms)

The conversion follows a few clear rules.

Vertices become RDF triples - Each vertex is converted into multiple RDF triples.

  • The vertex key becomes the subject
  • Each attribute becomes a predicate
  • Attribute values become objects

For example, a supplier like Alpha Metals becomes a set of triples such as:

<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/NAME> "Alpha Metals" .
<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/COUNTRY> "China" .
<http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/SUPPLIERID/S1> <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/RISKLEVEL> "High" .

This directly mirrors the rows in the vertex table.

Vertex types become rdf:type - Vertex labels are converted into RDF classes.

Conceptually, this means:

<Suppliers/S1> rdf:type <Supplier> .
<Materials/M1> rdf:type <Material> .

This adds semantic meaning and allows tools and queries to reason about what kind of thing each node represents.

Step 6: Mapping modes and URI control

By default, the system generates URIs automatically. These are predictable, but often not ideal for long term semantic use. To give users full control, the conversion supports an optional mapping table, where you can define: schema, table, attribute, RDF URI, data type, optional language tags.

Using a mapping table allows customers to:

  • apply meaningful, business-friendly URIs
  • align with existing vocabularies
  • standardize naming across systems

If a mapping table is not provided, the system falls back to sensible defaults:

  • URIs are generated in the form - https://localhost/<schema>/<table>/<attribute>
  • Vertex labels default to table names
  • Unmapped attributes are handled based on the selected mapping mode

This makes it easy to get started without extra configuration.

Mapping modes that fit different customer needs

The conversion supports multiple modes, depending on how strict or exploratory the user wants to be. These modes are also described in the official documentation. 

  • AUTO (default) - Uses mapping table entries when provided, otherwise generates system URIs.
  • MAPPING_ONLY - Generates mapping output without creating RDF. Useful for validation.
  • IGNORE - Converts only attributes explicitly listed in the mapping table.
  • STRICT - Requires all attributes to be mapped. Fails if anything is missing.

 You can also supply a mapping table to assign clean, meaningful URIs and prefixes, including standard vocabularies like FOAF. An out-mapping table is generated automatically so users can inspect exactly how attributes were mapped.

Step 7: Query the knowledge graph with SPARQL

Once the RDF graph is created, it can be queried directly inside SAP HANA Cloud using SPARQL_TABLE or SPARQL_EXECUTE functions.

View the RDF graph created:

SELECT *
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
PREFIX rdf:<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX ex:<http://example.org/scm/>

SELECT ?subject ?predicate ?obj
FROM <scmkg>
WHERE {
  ?subject ?predicate ?obj .
}
');

The below SPARQL query retrieves which suppliers ship which materials by traversing shipment relationships in the converted knowledge graph.

SELECT *
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
SELECT DISTINCT ?supplierName ?materialName
FROM <scmkg>
WHERE {
  # ensure the embedded shipment triple exists
  FILTER EXISTS {
     << ?supplier <http://SCM/SHIPMENTS/SHIPMENTS> ?material >> ?p ?o .
  }
  # supplier attributes
  ?supplier <http://SCM/SUPPLIERS/NAME> ?supplierName .
  # material attributes
  ?material <http://SCM/MATERIALS/NAME> ?materialName .
}
');

The same data you modeled as a property graph is now available through standard SPARQL queries.

Key benefits for customers:

  1. Standardized representation - RDF makes data interoperable across tools, platforms, and organizational boundaries.
  2. Richer semantics - Customers can define precise meanings through URIs, classes, and vocabularies.
  3. Easy integration with AI - Knowledge graphs are becoming foundational for RAG systems and reasoning. This conversion gives customers a clean way to prepare their graph data for LLM based applications.
  4. No need to duplicate data models - Users start with property graphs and layer semantics later as needed.
  5. Works with existing HANA Cloud graph workspaces - Nothing special is required on the modeling side.

Looking ahead

This blog is intended as an introduction and starting point for the new Property Graph to Knowledge Graph conversion capability in SAP HANA Cloud. It represents the first step toward deeper interoperability between the property graph engine and the knowledge graph engine. The long-term vision is to reduce barriers between the two and allow users to move freely between graph patterns as their needs evolve. On our roadmap, we also plan to support conversion in the opposite direction, from knowledge graphs back to property graphs, helping to close the loop.

As graph workloads continue to grow inside SAP HANA Cloud, customers increasingly want both modeling flexibility and semantic power. With this new PG to KG conversion feature, we provide an easy entry point into the world of knowledge graphs without changing how data is modeled or stored today.

This blog focuses on introducing the core concepts and mechanics in simpler terms. In a follow-up blog, I look forward to diving deeper into a real-world use case example and exploring advanced mappings and scenarios that this capability is designed to handle.

entry.title: End-to-End Message Tracking and Retry Control in SAP Cloud integration
entry.content:
In this post, we’ll explore an end-to-end asynchronous scenario where the sender is XI (Proxy) and the receiver is an API. The goal is to avoid infinite JMS retries, persist messages in JMS queues, and track them effectively in SAP Cloud Integration (CI) monitoring.

 

Scenario Overview

For message processing from the S/4HANA sender system, we use a common artifact that:

  • Determines whether the message is sync or async (via a Sync Call Router).
  • For async messages, routes them into a common JMS queue.
  • For sync messages, dynamically identifies the preceding iFlow based on sender interface and namespace.

 

 

 

The next iFlow:

  • Reads messages from the common JMS queue.
  • Dynamically determines the preceding iFlow using Sender Interface Name and Namespace.

 

Retry Configuration

In my case, maximum retries are set to 6. Here’s how it works:

 

  1. Message delivered on first attempt
    → No retry triggered; message reaches the end system successfully.
  2. Message fails but succeeds within retry limit (e.g., 4th attempt)
    → Each retry invokes the exception subprocess, which calls the local integration process (max retry condition) until the threshold is reached.

 

  1. Maximum retry condition reached
    → Message is routed to the exception subprocess, then moved to a quarantine queue.
    → An email notification is sent to stakeholders for further action.

 

 

The Catch: Tracking and Reprocessing Messages

While many posts cover retries and exception handling, the key challenge is tracking a specific message and moving it back to the original queue for reprocessing (a feature introduced in Q3 2025).

 

For XI messages:

  • Retrieve SAP Message ID from SXMB_MONI.

 

  • Add it to CI Camel header values (SAP_ApplicationID).

 

Useful Identifiers

  • ${SapMessageId} → XI Adapter Message ID (uppercase, no dashes)
  • ${SapMessageIdEx} → XI Adapter Message ID (lowercase, with dashes)
  • ${header.SAP_DataStoreRetries} → Retry count for DataStore
  • ${header.SAPJMSRetries} → Retry count for JMS

 

Steps to Reprocess

  1. Identify the last retried message using Correlation ID in CI Monitoring.

 

  1. Locate the message in the quarantine queue using the Message ID from the message and search the same in your quarantine queue

 

 

The message identified in quarantine queue.

 

  1. After stakeholder deliberation:
    • Move the message back to the original queue for reprocessing.
    • Delete if no longer needed.
    • Or retain in quarantine (monitor JMS resources to avoid exhaustion).

 

Summary

  • We explained how to restrict retries in CI to prevent endless JMS loops and also avoid storage exhaustion.
  • We also covered tracking messages that hit retry limits and taking subsequent actions (move, delete, or retain).

entry.title: Extending SAP Asset Performance Management: Three Approaches to Tailoring Your Asset Operations
entry.content:
In asset management, no two organizations operate the same way. While standard software provides a robust foundation, the ability to adapt to industry-specific regulations and distinct business processes is where you find your true efficiency.

At SAP, we understand this need for flexibility. That's why SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) is built on a modern, cloud-native architecture designed to be extended. Whether you are a customer, partner, or consultant, this blog highlights how you can leverage APM’s extensibility options to build tailored, value-added solutions.

 

Why Extensibility Matters

Extensibility is not just a technical feature - it's what makes APM work the way your business actually runs. By extending the solution, you can:

  • Address industry-specific needs by closing functional gaps that matter in your daily operations.
  • Enhance user productivity with role-focused UIs that cut out unnecessary clicks and complexities.
  • Integrate seamlessly with your existing IT landscape without disrupting the core application.

Here are the three main ways you can customize APM. The first two methods are also collectively known as SaaS Extensibility.

1. Extending Data and Services (OData APIs)

The foundation of any custom solution is data. APM provides robust OData APIs that let you add new data fields without modifying the core structure.

What You Can Do

A. Add custom fields and custom entities

Need to track "Compliance Due Date" or the "Safety Criticality Level" on a specific recommendation? You can extend existing entities with additional fields or create entirely new entities to capture this critical information, without changing the standard application model.

  • Custom entities are customer-defined data structures that allow organizations to store and manage business information beyond the standard application model.
  • Custom fields are customer-defined attributes added to an existing entities to capture additional business-specific information.

B. Build custom applications

Develop custom applications using extended services (APIs) to introduce new business logic or functionalities that complement APM.

=> Learn how to extend ODATA APIs in CAP: Extending the Data Model

2. Customizing the User Interface (UI)

Once you have the right data, you need to present it effectively. APM offers robust options for extending SAP Fiori-based applications to match your workflow.

What You Can Do:

  • Show Your Custom Fields: Make your custom data (like that "Compliance Due Date") visible as a new column in lists like Manage Recommendations or as a new field in details pages.
  • Organize Information: Group related information together. For example, you could create a specific "Safety Assessment and Financial Analysis" tab on the Recommendation page to put all risk mitigation and cost benefit details in one easy to find spot.
  • Smart Controls: Change how data looks and control how fields are rendered – like changing a text input to a dropdown list for consistency or reordering fields to prioritize key data.

=> Learn how to extend UI5 Fiori based applications: Extending UI Annotations

Example 1: Recommendation Object Page showing new custom fields for Version tracking in the Header and Information section.

Example 2: Recommendation Object Page showing a custom 'Attachments' tab with external links and sensitivity details

Example 3: Recommendation Object Page showing new custom fields for ‘Integrity Critical’ and ‘Run-to-Fail' status

 

Example 4: Recommendation List Page showing new columns and filters for custom fields - Version, Integrity Criticality, Run to Fail status

 

3. Adapting for Different Users

Different people need different things. APM leverages the SAPUI5 Extensibility framework, offering three levels of customization so everyone has the right view.

A. End User Personalization ("My View")

  • Who: Individual Users

  • What: Users can save their own filter settings as "Variants" (e.g., "Critical Rotor Failures Q3"), add shortcuts to objects you use often, and move applications around on the Fiori Launchpad.

  • Why: Increases individual efficiency without requiring IT support.

=> Learn more about SAPUI5 Flexibility for End Users: End User Personalization

B. Key User Adaptation ("Our View")

  • Who: Business Experts / Key Users
  • What: Using intuitive, no-code tools, key users can adapt the UI for entire teams. This includes hiding irrelevant fields, renaming labels to match internal terminology, or creating shared views for specific roles (e.g., an "Operations View" vs. a "Reliability View").
  • Why: Tailors the application for specific teams without writing custom code.

=> Learn more about SAPUI5 Flexibility for Key Users: Key User Adaptation

=> How to Begin with Key User Adaptation: Adapting SAP Fiori UIs at Runtime

C. Developer Adaptation ("Custom Code")

  • Who: Professional Developers

  • What: For complex requirements, developers can use SAP Business Application Studio to inject custom UI components, integrate external data services, or implement complex logic.

  • Why: Solves unique, complex business challenges while keeping the core app safe and updatable.

Note: Developer Adaptation is currently not supported in APM.

 

Getting Started

We want to make extending APM as easy as possible. To help you start quickly, we provide:

  • Template Projects: Downloadable SAP CAP projects pre-configured for extending specific APM applications. These include the basic code and test data to speed up development.
  • Step-by-Step Guides: Step-by-step documentation covering everything from setting up your test tenant to deploying and maintaining your extensions.

Best Practices for Success

To ensure your extensions are robust and future-proof, keep these principles in mind:

  • Don't Break the Core: Always use the provided frameworks (OData extensions, UI Adaptation) rather than modifying core code.
  • Focus on Value: Focus on extensions that address a clear business need and add tangible value to your users.
  • Design for Stability: Write clean, modular and secure code that is easy to maintain and scale.
  • Keep it Secure: Adhere to SAP security guidelines for data access and authorization.
  • Performance Aware: Make sure you extensions don’t slow down the core application, especially if you are working with large datasets.
  • Test Rigorously: Ensure your extensions function correctly under various scenarios.

Conclusion

Extensibility is the key to getting the most out of your asset management strategy. By leveraging these tools, you can transform APM into a solution that fits your business perfectly - driving greater efficiency, intelligence, and operational excellence.

Ready to get started? Check out the official documentation and our architectural guidelines to begin tailoring APM to your unique needs today.

entry.title: New Cross Encoder and Text Embedding support Dimensionality Reduction in HANA NLP Service 2025 Q4
entry.content:
New Cross Encoder and Text Embedding support Dimensionality Reduction in HANA NLP Service 2025 Q4 

With the SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4 release, several new embedded Machine Learning / AI and NLP functions have been released with the SAP HANA Cloud Predictive Analysis Library (PAL). Key new capabilities to be highlighted are introduction of cross-encoder and dimensionality reduction supported in embedding models. An enhancement summary is available in the What’s new document for SAP HANA Cloud database 2025.40 (QRC 4/2025).

Cross Encoder Model

The NLP service has been enhanced with the addition of a new ​cross-encoder model. The existing embedding model in the service can be considered a ​bi-encoder model. These two model architectures differ in their design and application. In general, ​bi-encoder models are faster but less accurate than cross-encoder models, making them suitable for the retrieval phase. In contrast, cross-encoder models offer higher accuracy at the cost of slower speed, making them ideal for the re-ranking stage.

A cross encoder is a neural network model that processes two inputs, such as a query and a document, together to determine their relationship or similarity, outputting a relevance score. Unlike bi-encoders, which encode inputs separately into vectors, cross encoders analyze the interaction between the input pair simultaneously, allowing for precise semantic understanding and high-accuracy results, particularly in re-ranking tasks within information retrieval.

Advantages

  • High Accuracy: Their ability to model interactions directly results in superior accuracy for semantic comparison tasks compared to bi-encoders.
  • Precision: They excel at tasks where precise relevance assessment is crucial, such as re-ranking.

Disadvantages

  • Computational Cost: Due to the need to process the query and each document together, cross encoders are computationally expensive and slow for large-scale search applications.
  • Limited to Pairs: They can only process input pairs, meaning they cannot be used to generate individual embeddings for each document.

     

Advanced RAG

The cross-encoder model can be combined with an existing embedding model to form a retrieve and rerank pipeline, which can be referred to as an ​Advanced RAG​ architecture. In this pipeline, the ​bi-encoder model is responsible for screening the candidate set, while the ​cross-encoder model performs re-ranking on this candidate set to deliver superior results​.

The detailed steps are as follows:

  1. ​Passages are pre-vectorized and stored: The passages(documents/chunks) are converted into vectors in advance using the embedding model and stored in vector database (HANA).

  2. ​Query vectorization and initial retrieval (normal RAG)​: When a query arrives, it is also converted into a vector using the same embedding model. A vector search (e.g., using cosine similarity) is then performed to find the top-K most similar passages as the candidate set. If these top-K results are directly used for subsequent text generation, this constitutes what is generally considered normal RAG.

  3. ​Re-ranking with Cross-Encoder (The Advanced RAG step)​: The candidate set serves as input to the cross-encoder model. The cross-encoder jointly processes the query with each candidate passage to compute a more precise relevance score. It then re-ranks the candidate set based on these scores. These re-ranked results are returned for text generation, completing all the steps of Advanced RAG.

     

     

benchmark

vs bi-encoder benchmark

A benchmark evaluation of the re-ranking capability using a cross-encoder is conducted. The test was performed on English retrieval tasks from the MTEB benchmark. An embedding model was first used to retrieve an initial candidate set of size 40, which was then re-ranked by the cross-encoder. The results are shown in the figure below.

It can be observed that for all datasets under the retrieval task, the cross-encoder demonstrated a significant improvement over the embedding model. Using the metric NDCG@10, the most substantial improvement was observed on one dataset, where the score increased from 0.57 to 0.8. The average value across all datasets improved from 0.47 to 0.55.

vs opensource models

We conducted a comprehensive benchmark evaluation by selecting six popular open-source cross-encoder models from HuggingFace, including models such as MS-MARCO and BGE-Reranker, along with several larger-scale variants. The evaluation methodology involved using the same bi-encoder model to generate candidate sets for all cross-encoders, and comparing their re-ranking performance across varying candidate pool sizes.

The results indicate that, across different candidate set sizes, the model in question achieves the highest performance among all evaluated models. Furthermore, we extended the comparison to include several bi-encoders built on large language models (LLMs) with over 7 billion parameters. Notably, the proposed pipeline demonstrates competitive performance compared to these LLM-based bi-encoders, despite utilizing a base-sized model with less than 3% of the parameter count.

Use with Python

Cross encoder API is available in our python package hana_ai. Here is an example of advanced RAG, the query is:

"when did athens emerges as wealthiest greek city state"

  1. Use the following code to load the PALCrossEncoder model class.
from hana_ai.vectorstore.pal_cross_encoder import PALCrossEncoder
 
  1. Establish a connection with the HANA database.
from hana_ml import dataframe
conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address=host,
                                   port=port,
                                   user=user,
                                   password=password)
 
  1. Load the corpus vector table.
corpus_vecs_df = conn.table('NQ_CORPUS_EMBEDDING')
corpus_vecs_df.head(3).collect()

 

  1. Retrieve the top-K candidate set for the query. At this stage, the target document is ranked 14th, which is relatively low. Therefore, using these results for text generation often yields limited outcomes or consumes a significant number of tokens.
retrieve_results = corpus_vecs_df.sort_by_similarity('embedding', query = nq_query[query_id_index]['text'], model_version= "SAP_GXY.20250407").head(k).collect()

 

 

5. Use the cross encoder model to re-rank the candidate set. After re-ranking, the target text moves to the first position, significantly improving the retrieval outcome.

cross_encoder = PALCrossEncoder(conn)
pairs = [[query, passage] for passage in retrieve_results['text']]
cross_encoder_results = cross_encoder.predict(pairs)

 

use with SQL

Here shows how to use the cross encoder model in SQL with our SQL function PAL_CROSSENCODER.

SET SCHEMA DM_PAL;

DROP TABLE CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL;
CREATE COLUMN TABLE CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL (
    "ID" INTEGER,
    "TEXT1" NCLOB,
    "TEXT2" NCLOB
);
INSERT INTO DM_PAL.CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL VALUES (0, 'Interstellar is a 2014 epic science fiction film co-written, directed, and produced by Christopher Nolan.', 'Interstellar was nominated for five awards at the 87th Academy Awards, winning Best Visual Effects, and received numerous other accolades');
INSERT INTO DM_PAL.CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL VALUES (1, 'It stars Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, Bill Irwin, Ellen Burstyn, Matt Damon, and Michael Caine.', 'It has also received praise from many astronomers for its scientific accuracy and portrayal of theoretical astrophysics. Since its premiere, Interstellar gained a cult following,[5] and now is regarded by many sci-fi experts as one of the best science-fiction films of all time.');
INSERT INTO DM_PAL.CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL VALUES (2, 'Interstellar uses extensive practical and miniature effects and the company Double Negative created additional digital effects.', 'Interstellar relies heavily on practical and miniature models, while digital effects were enhanced by the visual effects studio Double Negative.');


DROP TABLE PAL_CROSS_ENCODER_PARAMETER_TBL;
CREATE COLUMN TABLE PAL_CROSS_ENCODER_PARAMETER_TBL(
	"PARAM_NAME" NVARCHAR(256), 
	"INT_VALUE" INTEGER, 
	"DOUBLE_VALUE" DOUBLE,
	"STRING_VALUE" NVARCHAR(1000)
);
INSERT INTO PAL_CROSS_ENCODER_PARAMETER_TBL VALUES('MODEL_VERSION', NULL, NULL, 'SAP_CER.20250701');

CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_CROSSENCODER(CROSS_ENCODER_TEXT_TBL, PAL_CROSS_ENCODER_PARAMETER_TBL, ?, ?);
 

Text Embedding Service supports Dimensionality Reduction

Now text embedding service supports dimensionality reduction. When using the embedding service, you only need to specify the specific dimension to obtain the low-dimensional version of the vector. Detailed introduction to embedding models that support dimensionality reduction can be found here.

The model enhances a standard embedding model by incorporating a trained linear layer optimized via Principal Component Analysis (PCA). This layer performs vector dimensionality reduction and is trained on a large-scale dataset comprising over 700 million samples.

Key features of the model include: ​Lightweight and flexible dimensionality reduction​ that can be deployed as an integrated component following an embedding model or used independently to process pre-computed vectors (e.g., within SAP HANA). Support for ​dynamic output dimension selection, though we strongly recommend a reduction to ​256 dimensions​ for optimal balance between size and accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that reducing embeddings to 256 dimensions retains retrieval accuracy comparable to the full-dimensional vectors, while reducing storage footprint to approximately one-third and improving vector search speed. However, further reduction below 128 dimensions leads to significant degradation in accuracy. It is recommended to use 256 dimensions.

Embedding models supporting ​dimensionality reduction​ can be effectively combined with the latest ​cross‑encoder models​ to form a complementary ​retrieve‑and‑rerank pipeline. Test results show that this combined approach delivers ​nearly identical accuracy​ compared to using full‑dimensional embedding models together with cross‑encoder rerankers. At the same time, the resulting ​vector database is only one‑third the original size, and the ​computational load of retrieval is also reduced to one‑third. This strategy achieves an ​optimal balance among speed, efficiency, and accuracy.

Usage

Python

from hana_ml.text.pal_embeddings import PALEmbeddings
embedder = PALEmbeddings(
    model_version='SAP_GXY.20250407', # SAP_NEB.20240715 is also supported
    pca_dim_num=256 #support dim: 64, 128, 256, 384, 512, 768
    )
result = embedder.fit_transform(
    data=text, # text is a hana_ml.dataframe.DataFrame object
    key='id', # the key in thee dataframe
    target='text' # the column needed to be embedded, also supported multi-columns, for example: ['text1','text2']
    )

entry.title: Securing SAP Business AI Architectures: Trust Boundaries and Secure Data Flows
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance for SEA and is a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP), awarded by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). In this role, Jana supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction

AI is no longer an isolated innovation experiment in enterprises. It is becoming deeply embedded in core business processes. In the SAP ecosystem, this evolution has created a rich but multi-layered landscape: embedded machine learning in applications, side-by-side AI on SAP BTP,  generative AI via SAP Generative AI Hub and Joule as an AI copilot. A common question from customers, architects, and privacy professionals alike is: “What architectural models sit behind SAP Business AI use cases, and what are the trust boundaries for my data and the security of data flows in SAP Business AI?”

This blog answers that question by explaining SAP Business AI through clear architecture patterns. Each pattern is designed for different business needs, risk levels, and degrees of customization. Instead of individual products, we focus on how data flows, where intelligence runs, how access is controlled, and how compliance is maintained. This blog is intended for conceptual understanding, not detailed configuration guidance.

Embedded AI

The Embedded AI architecture pattern represents SAP’s approach to executing machine learning directly within the cloud applications system boundary such as S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors or other cloud applications. In this model, intelligence is built into the digital core itself rather than being consumed from external AI services.

When a user action or business process triggers a prediction request, the ABAP application layer does not transmit data outside the system. Instead, it invokes Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), which determines the appropriate machine learning scenario, model version, and execution logic. ISLM then orchestrates execution within the SAP HANA database, where algorithms from the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) or Automated Predictive Library (APL) run in-memory, directly alongside the transactional data.

Once the prediction is computed, the result flows back through ISLM to the ABAP layer and is immediately consumed by the business process. At no point does enterprise data leave the S/4HANA trust boundary.

The critical advantage of this pattern is zero data movement. Sensitive business data remains entirely within the S/4HANA system, making Embedded AI the strongest posture for strict data-minimization / no-egress requirements and deterministic option for transaction-specific, real-time predictions such as credit risk scoring, demand forecasting, delivery date prediction, or invoice blocking decisions.

Secure Data Flow

  1. User/Process triggers a prediction in the business process.
  2. ABAP application layer initiates the ML call (often via DB-proximate execution).
  3. ISLM orchestration / scenario management selects the scenario/model.
  4. HANA executes PAL/APL algorithms next to the business data (in-memory).
  5. Prediction result returns to the business process.

Aspect

How Embedded AI Addresses It

Data Residency

All processing occurs within the customer’s S/4HANA instance. Data never crosses network boundaries or leaves the system landscape, supporting strict data sovereignty and localization requirements (for example, GDPR and regional regulations).

Access Control

Embedded AI leverages existing SAP authorization concepts (roles, profiles, authorization objects). Users can only access predictions for business objects they are already authorized to view or process—no separate IAM layer is required.

Audit Trail

ISLM maintains comprehensive logs covering model training, deployment, and inference execution. These integrate with SAP’s standard logging and audit mechanisms (for example, application logs and system logs) to support compliance and audit reporting.

Data Encryption

Data protection relies on SAP HANA’s native encryption mechanisms for data at rest and in transit. No additional encryption layers are required, as data does not leave the internal system boundary.

Model Governance

ISLM enforces model lifecycle governance, including version control, approval workflows, and transport management. ML models follow the same change and release controls as ABAP code, ensuring consistent governance.

Third-Party Exposure

Unlike side-by-side AI or external LLM patterns, no data is transmitted to third-party AI providers. This eliminates external vendor trust dependencies and reduces the need for additional data processing agreements.

 

Side-by-side AI inference on SAP BTP using SAP AI Core

 This pattern keeps the digital core clean by running AI inference side-by-side on SAP BTP. A user interacts with a Fiori app, the request is handled by a BTP application (CAP/Node.js), and inference is executed in SAP AI Core inside a managed runtime (Docker container). The important security idea is that the user does not call the model directly. The BTP application is the controlled middleware that enforces authentication, authorization, and data minimization before sending anything for inference.

  1. Request Initiation: A user interacts with an SAP Fiori Application, which triggers an inference request (e.g., a text prompt or data for classification).
  2. CAP Middleware Layer: The request is sent to a Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model or Node.js service. This layer acts as the orchestrator and security gatekeeper.
  3. Authentication: The CAP service uses an OAuth2 Client Credentials flow, facilitated by an SAP AI Core Service Key, to exchange credentials for a secure JSON Web Token (JWT) via SAP’s XSUAA service.
  4. Inference Execution: The authenticated request is passed to SAP AI Core, which routes it to a specific Docker Container where the AI model is served.
  5. Response Handling: The model processes the input, generates a Response Payload, and sends it back through the CAP service to be rendered in the Fiori UI.

Step #

Flow Component

Security & Privacy Mechanism

Validation & Purpose (corrected)

1

Fiori App → CAP

User SSO via IdP/IAS; API protected via OAuth/JWT (often XSUAA); app RBAC

Request accepted only for authenticated users; app validates token and enforces role-based access.

2

CAP → AI Core

Service-to-service OAuth using service credentials (service key/binding); TLS; least privilege

CAP calls AI Core securely without hardcoding secrets in code; access scoped to required AI Core resources.

3

AI Core Runtime

Isolated container runtime (Docker); tenant/resource isolation; hardened images/secrets mgmt (recommended)

BYOM/model executes in a controlled AI Core runtime in the region where the service is provisioned (per availability).

4

Data Retrieval (RAG)

HANA Cloud Vector Engine; authorization-aware access; encryption at rest/in transit

Context retrieved from tenant-controlled vector store; embeddings can be stored in-region to support residency requirements.

5

Response Payload

Internal return path via BTP app; response validation; optional output filtering/redaction

Response returned to user through the CAP app. External calls happen only if architecture routes to external providers.

Secure Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with SAP Business AI:

Flow A represents the controlled ingestion and preparation phase where enterprise content is transformed into vector embeddings and securely stored for later retrieval. This phase is typically offline or asynchronous, which allows stronger governance and validation before any user interaction occurs.

Flow A – Ingestion (Preparation)

  1. A1 – Ingestion: Enterprise content is securely ingested from authorized SAP or customer-controlled sources using authenticated service access.
  2. A2 – Chunking: Content is split into smaller semantic segments to minimize data exposure and improve controlled retrieval.
  3. A3 – Embedding: Each chunk is converted into a vector via SAP-governed embedding models with ephemeral processing and no model training.
  4. A4 – Vector Storage: Generated embeddings are encrypted and stored in SAP HANA Cloud with tenant isolation and access control.

Flow B represents the runtime path, where a user question is answered using retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). The defining principle here is that context is retrieved first, validated, and only then sent to the LLM.

Flow B – Retrieval & Generation

  1. B1 – User Question: The user submits a query through an SAP application with identity and authorization already enforced.
  2. B2 – Query Embedding: The user query is transformed into a vector using the same secured embedding model for consistent matching.
  3. B3 – Vector Search: SAP HANA Cloud performs an authorization-aware similarity search to retrieve the top-K relevant vectors.
  4. B4 – Context Selection: Only the most relevant and permitted data chunks are selected as grounding context.
  5. B5 – LLM Invocation: The grounded context is sent via SAP GenAI Hub to generate a response with policy and safety guardrails applied.
  6. B6 – User Response: A grounded, auditable answer is returned to the user without persisting enterprise data in the LLM.

Orchestration Services in Gen AI Hub on SAP BTP

SAP Gen AI Hub on SAP BTP acts as the central orchestration and governance layer for generative AI, providing standardized and secure access to a broad range of Large Language Models (LLMs), including models hosted on SAP-managed infrastructure as well as selected third-party providers (such as Azure OpenAI, AWS, or Google), depending on the use case and region. Instead of exposing applications directly to LLMs, the GenAI Hub enforces a controlled, policy-driven interaction model.

The core flow for a secure user request includes:

  1. Prompt Templating: User prompts are normalized into approved templates with placeholders, ensuring consistency, reuse, and protection against prompt injection.
  2. Data Masking (Anonymization): Sensitive data, including personally identifiable information (PII), is dynamically masked or pseudonymized before the request is sent to the LLM.
  3. Content Filtering: Input and output filters inspect prompts and responses for unsafe, biased, or non-compliant content in line with SAP Responsible AI principles.
  4. Data Re-identification: After a safe response is returned, previously masked data may be selectively re-identified to restore business context for the end user, subject to policy controls.

This orchestration layer ensures customer data is minimized, protected, and never persistently stored or used for model training by external LLMs.

SAP AI Core: Execution & Lifecycle Management

While the GenAI Hub governs interaction and policy enforcement, SAP AI Core provides the standardized runtime for executing AI workloads on SAP Business Technology Platform. Key capabilities include:

  1. Model Serving: Machine learning models are deployed as scalable, secure inference services with managed lifecycle operations.
  2. Container-Based Execution: Custom AI workloads are packaged and deployed using Docker containers, enabling Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) scenarios with frameworks such as PyTorch or TensorFlow.
  3. Tenant Isolation: AI Core enforces strict isolation between tenants, ensuring that models, data, and execution environments remain segregated across customers.
  4. SAP AI Core ensures operational consistency, scalability, and security across both SAP-delivered and customer-developed AI use cases.

SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine: Grounding with Business Context

A key risk of generative AI is hallucination—responses that are fluent but not factually grounded. SAP addresses this using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). SAP HANA Cloud provides native vector capabilities that enable secure grounding of LLM responses in enterprise data:

  1. Embeddings & Similarity Search: Unstructured content (such as documents, policies, or contracts) is converted into vector embeddings and stored in the HANA Cloud Vector Engine.
  2. Grounded Retrieval: When a user prompt is processed, a similarity search retrieves the most relevant business context, which is injected into the LLM prompt—ensuring the generated response is based on authoritative, company-specific data. This approach significantly reduces hallucination risk while keeping enterprise data within SAP’s controlled data boundary.

The Centralized Control Plane: Scaling SAP Business AI Through GenAI Hub

 

This diagram shows a practical way to scale SAP Business AI securely: SAP applications consume AI through a single governed layer (GenAI Hub), while execution can happen either in SAP AI Core (including BYOM) or via approved external model providers. The key architectural decision here is to avoid "point-to-point AI integrations" where every app team separately manages model endpoints, credentials, and logging. Instead, GenAI Hub becomes the orchestration, trust, control, and routing layer—centralizing authentication/authorization, selecting the right model for each use case, and ensuring consistent telemetry across the landscape.

What Happens Under the Hood (Data Flow)

  1. A user triggers an AI feature from SAP applications such as S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, or SAP Fiori.
  2. The request is sent to GenAI Hub, which acts as the enterprise gateway for GenAI requests. At this point, GenAI Hub applies centralized controls: who is calling, what they are allowed to do, and which model endpoints are permitted. Critically, SAP applications never connect directly to LLM providersall requests flow through GenAI Hub, ensuring no credentials, tokens, or business data bypass the governance layer.
  3. GenAI Hub then routes the request down one of two execution paths:
    1. External approved model providers (e.g., Azure OpenAI, AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex AI, other approved models) when the use case allows external inference and the right provider is configured.
    2. SAP AI Core when you need SAP-managed runtime governance, want to run custom/BYOM models (PyTorch, TensorFlow), or require data to remain entirely within SAP's infrastructure.
  1. For grounding use cases (RAG), the flow can retrieve enterprise context from HANA Cloud Vector Engine, using vector indexing and similarity search to fetch the most relevant snippets. This makes responses more accurate and reduces hallucinations because the model is guided by trusted enterprise context rather than relying on the base model alone.
  2. The response returns through GenAI Hub back to the calling SAP application.

Security, Privacy, and AI Safety — Why This Pattern Matters

From a cybersecurity perspective, this design reduces attack surface by centralizing sensitive controls in one place. Authentication and authorization are enforced at the orchestration layer, model access is restricted to approved endpoints, and telemetry is standardized so security teams can monitor usage patterns, spikes, and anomalous behavior. When BYOM is used, SAP AI Core provides a managed container runtime where organizations can apply enterprise controls such as hardened images, secrets isolation, environment separation, and controlled deployment lifecycles. Importantly, SAP AI Launchpad provides the operational governance layer for AI Core (deploy, monitor, scale), helping prevent uncontrolled model changes in production.

From a data privacy and safety standpoint, the architecture supports "minimum necessary data" and better guardrails. Only required context should be sent for inference, and where external providers are used, this pattern naturally supports adding a trust layer (masking/tokenization and input/output filtering) before any data leaves the SAP boundary. SAP maintains strict contractual agreements with all external LLM providers, explicitly prohibiting customer data from being used for model training or retention beyond the inference session. For RAG, the vector store becomes a governed enterprise memory: the most important safety control is to ensure retrieval is authorization-aware, so users only see content they are entitled to access. Combined, these controls help customers adopt GenAI faster without losing control over data handling, residency decisions, auditability, and safety outcomes.

Enforcing Trust Boundaries in SAP Joule’s AI Execution Flow

 SAP Joule is a generative AI co-pilot natively embedded across SAP's cloud portfolio, including SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and SAP Concur. Running as a service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) in a Cloud Foundry environment, Joule leverages SAP's Generative AI Hub on SAP BTP to orchestrate secure interactions with Large Language Models. This architecture enables Joule to deliver contextually aware responses grounded in real business data while maintaining strict enterprise security and data privacy controls.

 

Step

The user enters a natural language prompt (e.g., "Change my address" or "Explain the travel policy") into the Joule interface.

2

Grounding (A, B, C)

Joule enriches the raw prompt by pulling from three sources:



(2A) Scenario Catalogue: Matches the intent to specific business functions (e.g., S/4HANA or SuccessFactors).



(2B) Knowledge Catalogue: Adds relevant SAP help or customer-specific documents via Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Security by Design in SAP Joule

Security in SAP Joule is not an afterthought. This is foundational to the architecture. Joule is built on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and inherits SAP’s enterprise-grade security controls across identity, access management, network protection, and continuous monitoring. This ensures AI-assisted interactions are governed with the same rigor as direct system access.

Authentication and Identity Management

SAP Joule relies on SAP Cloud Identity Services to authenticate users and manage identities consistently across SAP applications.

  • Identity Authentication Service (IAS) Authenticates users and verifies identity before granting access to Joule.
  • Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) Synchronizes users, roles, and attributes from source systems (such as SAP SuccessFactors) to SAP BTP, ensuring Joule reflects the user’s current authorizations.

This approach ensures Joule operates within the same identity framework as the underlying SAP landscape.

 OAuth 2.0 Authorization and Secure Access

  • Joule is deployed on SAP BTP and uses standard OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow for secure access.
  • User requests are routed through an SAP BTP AppRouter
  • XSUAA issues OAuth tokens based on the configured trust with the customer’s identity provider
  • Authentication follows the SAP BTP subaccount trust configuration

When accessing backend systems, Joule uses principal propagation, meaning it acts on behalf of the authenticated user. As a result, Joule can only perform actions and retrieve data that the user is already authorized to access in the native SAP application.

Role-Based Access Control

Joule does not introduce a separate permission model.

Instead:

  • It inherits role-based access control (RBAC) from the connected SAP applications
  • Authorization checks are enforced before any data access or function execution
  • AI-assisted interactions are consistent with direct application access

If a user cannot view data or execute a transaction in an SAP application, Joule will enforce the same restriction.

Encryption and Transport Security

All communication involving Joule is protected using strong encryption:

  • TLS 1.2 or higher for all data in transit
  • Secure communication with:
  • SAP backend systems (e.g., S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors)
  • SAP Generative AI Hub
  • Approved third-party LLM providers

Data at rest within SAP-managed cloud infrastructure is encrypted, with encryption keys handled through SAP’s centralized key management services.

Proactive Security and Continuous Governance

SAP applies multiple layers of proactive security controls to Joule:

  • Penetration Testing and Red Teaming Regular security testing to identify and remediate vulnerabilities.
  • Third-Party LLM Risk Management All LLM integrations undergo security, privacy, compliance, and ethical risk assessments before enablement.
  • Continuous Monitoring Real-time monitoring and incident response capabilities across SAP BTP and Joule services.
  • These measures ensure Joule remains resilient against evolving threats while meeting enterprise and regulatory expectations.

SAP Business AI Architecture Comparison

Even though SAP builds the AI architecture, customer, remain the pilot in command for risk acceptance and regulatory compliance. Understanding the "trust boundaries" of SAP Business AI allows customer to have informed conversations with your CISO, legal, and risk teams.

Four Critical Questions Every Leader Should Ask:

  • Data Residency: Where does my enterprise data stay, and where does it move during processing?
  • Execution Layer: Does this AI run inside the core system or on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)?
  • Grounding Method: Is the response purely generated by the model, or is it grounded in my specific business data?
  • Governance: What specific audit controls and security guardrails is SAP applying to this process?

SAP Business AI spans multiple architectural patterns, ranging from deterministic, in-stack machine learning to governed generative AI. Internally, SAP already maps every AI capability to one of these models based on:

  • The nature of the use case
  • Data sensitivity
  • Execution requirements
  • Regulatory and compliance considerations

For example:

  1. Embedded AI scenarios in SAP S/4HANA operate entirely within the digital core, with no data leaving the system boundary.
  2. Side-by-side AI scenarios execute on SAP Business Technology Platform, where SAP applications enforce authentication, authorization, and data minimization before invoking AI services.
  3. Generative AI scenarios that interact with enterprise data are implemented using secure Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), ensuring responses are grounded in authorized business context.
  4. Enterprise-scale copilots and cross-application AI capabilities are governed centrally through SAP GenAI Hub, with SAP AI Core providing controlled execution.
  5. Customers enable these models by activating AI use cases, not by architecting them.

This flexibility is backed by a consistent contractual and security framework for data processing, so customers have a predictable baseline across patterns. The intent is straightforward: whether AI is embedded in an application, hosted in SAP AI Core, or accessed via an approved external provider, the same privacy and security expectations should hold. When external models are involved, the architecture should add explicit protections data minimization and masking before egress, plus input/output filtering and continuous monitoring to reduce exposure risk and keep responses safe, compliant, and operationally governed.

entry.title: Re: How to Skip approver when user is repeated

Thank you for your patience.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is no standard configuration that automatically skips the same approver across multiple non-consecutive approval levels. If the same business user is determined again at a later step, the system will trigger a new approval step.

As a result, the recommended and feasible approach is to redesign the approval workflow to avoid overlapping approver roles across different approval levels.

entry.title: Integrated Financial Planning for Two-Tier ERP with SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Here you can find the important highlights of the Integrated Financial Planning for SAP S/4HANA for the current release.

In this blog post, we will look at how organizations can leverage Integrated Financial Planning for their Two-Tier ERP systems with SAP Analytics Cloud.

We start with an introduction to Headquarter Subsidiary hybrid deployment model. Next, we will see how SAP Analytics Cloud best integrates with SAP S/4HANA systems followed by a use case of how Headquarter (running on SAP S/4HANA On Premise) and Subsidiary (running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud) can perform Integrated Financial Planning in SAP Analytics Cloud. We then see in detail how Integration works in Financial Planning with an example. In the last section you find all important links, references to kick start & accelerate your financial planning journey with SAP Analytics Cloud.

Headquarter-Subsidiary Model - SAP’s Two-Tier deployment model with SAP S/4HANA Cloud provides integration capability among multiple tiers and helps standardize the processes across the Tiers. The semantic compatibility between the SAP S/4HANA Cloud data model and SAP S/4HANA On-Premise makes SAP’s Hybrid ERP strategy the best choice for deployment in a Headquarter-Subsidiary setup of MNCs. For details on the benefits & use case of Headquarter-Subsidiary deployment model.

SAP Analytics Cloud is fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA. Integrated Financial Planning for SAP S/4HANA business content comes with demo data in SAP Analytics Cloud and allows you to import your own data from SAP S/4HANA and to export your planning results back to SAP S/4HANA. The complete integration is part of the content delivery and is available out of the box. Revenue Planning, Cost Center Planning and Budgeting, Profitability Planning and Product Cost Simulation are based on the SAP S/4HANA data model in FI-CO and fully integrated with it.

Headquarter- Subsidiary deployment model - Use Case for Integrated Financial Planning Headquarter can do Group level business planning and input/edit to Integrated Financial Planning for Subsidiaries (on Actual data from Subsidiary system) in SAP Analytics Cloud. Different business users from both Headquarter and Subsidiary can get involved in the planning process.

 

 

 

The planning data in SAP Analytics Cloud can be exported back to SAP S/4HANA systems and is available in Analytical reports for comparison with the actuals (Apps like Cost Center-Plan/Actuals, Cost Center-Plan/Actuals YTD, Internal Order-Plan/Actuals, Internal Order-Plan/Actuals YTD). Activity Cost Rates and Statistical Key figures planned can also be exported back to SAP S/4HANA systems, for details refer here.

 

 

 

 

 
 

 

 

 

Landing Page

This content gives an overview of the financial planning scenarios of "Integrated Financial Planning for SAP S/4HANA" in SAP Analytics Cloud, such as cost center planning, product cost planning, and sales and profitability planning. There is also a section providing access to all administrative tasks. The Landing Page allows to jump directly to the respective planning stories and even dedicated pages, making it easier to navigate within planning.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Operating Expense Planning

This content facilitates the complete operating expense planning, based on cost center and WBS element, including expense planning, allocations, activity quantity planning and activity cost rate calculation, as well as capturing project expense budgets and plans based on work breakdown structures (WBS elements).

 

It also supports the planning administrator with powerful functions to prepopulate the planning screens based on past actual data. This process can be integrated with availability control functionality and budget consistency checks in SAP S/4HANA.

 

Analytics and Reporting stories provide you with KPIs and interactive overview charts and give you insights into the cost center plan data along the GL account hierarchy by activity type and partner information.

 

The following features are supported:

  • Expense planning
  • Allocations
  • Activity quantity planning
  • Activity cost rate planning
  • Activity cost rate calculation

 

A typical planning story has central story filters, triggers for planning functions and a table for data entry: (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CCtrExpenses)

 

The planning results can be visualized in analytic stories:

 

 

 

 

Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Planning 

Story (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_ActivityCostRatePlanning) allows you to use the actual data from last year as a planning proposal for the activity output quantities and activity cost rates. You can adjust output quantities and prices both on an aggregated level and on the level of partner cost centers. The costs are then calculated by multiplying the quantity with the price. The system can also determine output quantities based on receiving cost centers by means of inverse calculation of activity quantities. You can distribute the total activity output to receiving cost centers using the indirect activity allocation rule. You can plan the capacity of a cost center manually and compare it to the planned activity output.

 

 

 

The story uses the following data actions:

 

  • Calculate cost center costs (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateCCtrCosts) (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_AllocateCCtrActivityQuantities)

 

Allocate cost center activity quantities between cost centers based on a driver that is maintained on cost center level.

 

  • Calculate cost center activity quantities inversely (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateCCtrActivityQuantities)

 

Calculate activity quantities of a sender cost center based on the activity quantities of the receiving cost center.

 

  • Calculate cost center costs (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateCCtrCosts)

 

Each cost center activity quantity record is multiplied with this price to calculate the costs. Technically, this runs on credit values. 

 

  • Copy credit cost center activity quantities from actuals (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CopyCreditCCtrActivityQuantitiesFromActuals

 

Copy cost center activity quantities from last year's actuals into a plan version. Technically, credit cost center quantities are copied. The cost center quantities are assigned to the G/L account that is assigned to the activity type.

 

  • Copy credit cost center activity quantities from product cost plan (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CopyCreditCCtrActivityQuantitiesFromProductCost)

 

Copy credit cost center activity quantities from product cost plan

 

  • Derive activity cost rates from actuals (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_DeriveActivityCostRatesFromActuals)

 

Calculates the average activity cost rate of the previous year and applies it to all plan periods.

 

Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Calculation

The Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Calculation story (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_ActivityCostRateCalculation) allows you to calculate activity prices based on the planning of cost center expenses. You can allocate activity-independent expenses to activity types based on the weights that you’ve defined in the Operating Expense Planning Administration story (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_PlanAdmin). You can also manually plan activity-dependent expenses.

You must have completed the Cost Center Expense Planning story (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CCtrExpenses) before you can work on this story.

 

The story uses the following data actions:

  • Calculate cost center activity cost rates (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateCCtrActivityCostRates)

 

Calculate cost center activity cost rates by dividing aggregated cost center expenses by the activity quantity. The price is calculated as an average year price and stored with the same value into each period with the account of the activity type. After that, each activity quantity record is multiplied with this price to calculate the costs. Technically, this runs on credit values. The debits are calculated afterwards by switching cost center / activity type with partner cost center / partner activity type and multiplying by -1.

  • Calculate cost center activity cost rates with account-based split (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateCCtrActivityCostRatesWithAccountSplit)

 

Calculate cost center activity cost rates by dividing aggregated cost center expenses by the activity quantity. The price is calculated as an average year price and stored with the same value into each period. After that, each activity quantity record is multiplied with this price to calculate the costs. Technically, this runs on credit values. The debits are calculated afterwards by switching cost center / activity type with partner cost center / partner activity type and multiplying by -1

 

.

  • Calculate variable costs (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CalculateVariableCosts)

 

Calculate variable costs based on activity output and a driver that is maintained on cost center, cost center activity type, and account level.

 

  • Copy cost center expenses from actuals (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CopyCCtrExpensesFromActuals)

 

Copy actuals cost center expenses from last year into a plan version. Technically, debit amounts are copied. Existing expenses in the plan version are deleted before the copy.

 

  • Copy credit cost center activity quantities from actuals (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CopyCreditCCtrActivityQuantitiesFromActuals)

 

Copy cost center activity quantities from last year's actuals into a plan version. Technically, credit cost center quantities are copied. The cost center quantities are assigned to the G/L account that is assigned to the activity type.

 

  • Copy credit cost center activity quantities from product cost plan (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_CopyCreditCCtrActivityQuantitiesFromProductCost)

 

Copy credit cost center activity quantities from product cost plan

 

  • Split cost center expenses by activity type (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_SplitCCtrActivityType)

 

Split cost center costs down to activity types based on a driver that is maintained on cost center / activity type level.

 

  • Split cost center expenses by fix/variable code (SAP_FI_IFP_IM_OPEX_SplitCCtrFixVar)

 

Split cost center /activity type costs by fix and variable parts based on a driver that is maintained on G/L account level.

For me, these below two solutions are working.

Method 1: The ODBC Local Connector (Pull via Gateway)

Download the SAP Hana Clients tools 2.0 from SAP tools for ODBC Connectors and have your Space Database Details ready like User Name, Host, Password, etc. Ready. [Like Below Snapshot]

Insert the details earlier copied from database user here i,e. Host Name, Port and next page it will ask for credentials and then ok.

It might give you error like this below, coz the external IP need to be whitelisted by SAP Data Sphere System Admin.

SAP Data Sphere  Sytem Configuration The IP Allowlist the device IP should be added in the allowlist, otherwise it will work. [External Machine IP not the IP shows]

Now go on, Fabric/Powerbi Bi sides, after connectin is succesfull.

Get Data > ODBC then connect the connection we created will show up there.

Connect with the data.


Method 2: The API Approach (Notebooks & Data Pipelines)

entry.title: How to Test OAuth-Enabled Inbound Communication in SAP Using an API Client
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog post explains how to test OAuth-enabled inbound communication in SAP using an API client. It walks through the configuration steps and provides practical examples for validating the setup.

When working with inbound communication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud or on-premises systems, developers and integration specialists often need a lightweight tool to test APIs secured with OAuth 2.0.

While there are many API testing tools available today, this guide focuses on Bruno—a modern, open-source similar to the more established Postman. Personally I think of Postman as the old guard, and Bruno as the new pup on the block: sleek, efficient, and eager to fetch your tokens! (And yes, my love for dogs may have influenced this choice just a little.) 
                                                                         

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 🐾 In this post, I’ll walk you through how to:

  1. Configure a custom communication arrangement based on an existing communication scenario for OAuth 2.0
  2. Use an API client to test inbound communication secured with OAuth 2.0

Note: This guide assumes you already have a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0.

Prerequisites

  • A communication scenario in your S/4HANA system that supports OAuth 2.0
  • An API client installed on your operating system (for example, Bruno, Postman, or any equivalent tool)

So, grab your treats and let’s get our paws dirty—Bruno’s ready to sniff out those OAuth tokens and help you unleash smoother integrations!

Step 1: Enable a Custom Communication Arrangement for OAuth

1. Create a Communication System and Communication User

🐾 Think of the Communication System as Bruno’s doghouse—it needs to be cozy, secure, and ready for visitors. 🐾

Open the Communication Systems app and create a new system:

System IDZ_BRUNO
System NameZ_BRUNO


Under Technical Data:

  1. Enable Inbound Only.
  2. In OAuth 2.0 Settings: 
    • Set Client Redirect URI Type to Loopback
    • Set a path in the Path field, e.g., /bruno/redirect
          → This becomes your Callback URL:   http://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect (used in Step 2)

🐾 When you set the redirect path to /bruno/redirect, you’re basically telling Bruno where to wag his tail when he’s done fetching the token. 🐾

Under Users for Inbound Communication

  1.  Add a new communication user
  2.  Set Authentication Method to OAuth 2.0
  3.  Define OAuth 2.0 Client ID, e.g., Z_BRUNO_ID
  4. Enable Refresh Allowed and set Refresh Token Expiry Time, e.g., 5 Days

Save your communication system and inbound communication user for your future testing with Bruno acting as OAuth client. This user will be later used for the Authorization Code Grant with PKCE.

2. Create a Communication Arrangement

Open the Communication Arrangements app and create a new arrangement based on a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0 as an authentication method, e.g., SAP_COM_0053 (Purchase Order Integration).

ScenarioSAP_COM_0053 (exists only in S/4HANA Cloud)
Arrangement NameTEST_COM_0053_WITH_BRUNO
Communication System Z_BRUNO (defined earlier)

Under Inbound Communication:

 

  1. Enter the OAuth 2.0 Client ID you defined earlier: Z_BRUNO_ID.
  2. Save your communication arrangement.

Note: Only after saving the arrangement, the previously defined OAuth client gets actually created. A clickable label OAuth 2.0 Details will apear.

In OAuth 2.0 Details, you will find all the necessary data for your API client:

  1. Client ID
  2. Token Service URL
  3.  Authorization URL

These are needed to fetch a token with Bruno.

Now you are ready to test your OAuth-secured API using Bruno!


Step 2: Use Bruno to Test the OAuth Communication

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 

 

1. Create a New Collection

🐾  Creating a new collection in Bruno is like giving your dog a new toy—name it, set it up, and let the fun begin!  🐾

  1. Open Bruno
  2. Create a New Collection
  3. Name it, e.g., My_test_collection

2. Set Up OAuth in the Auth Tab

  1. Go to the Auth tab and choose OAuth 2.0
  2. Set up the configurations:

     

Grant TypeAuthorization Code
Callback URLhttp://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect
Authorization URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Access Token URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Client IDFrom Communication Arrangement
Statedummy
Use PKCE check box✅enabled

🐾  Don’t forget to enable PKCE—it’s like putting a leash on your OAuth flow. Keeps things secure and under control. 🐾

3. Send a Test Request

  1. Choose Get Access Token
  2. A browser window will open -  logon as a Business User
  3. Approve the request by clicking Allow

  4. If successful, you’ll receive an Access Token. 
    The response typically appears in the Response tab in JSON format like this:

     

  5. Use this token to call your API services:


Troubleshooting Tips

  • Make sure you log in with a Business User assigned to the correct Business Roles for the API.
  • If you see the following screen after logging in:

it likely means the user lacks the required authorizations or the wrong user was used.

Summary

With this setup, you can securely test OAuth-protected endpoints in SAP using Bruno or similar tools. This approach is useful for validating integration scenarios and troubleshooting authentication issues.

Bruno provides a clean and open-source alternative to Postman for testing OAuth-secured APIs in SAP S/4HANA. With just a few configuration steps, you can simulate real-world OAuth flows and validate your communication scenarios with ease.

🐾 With Bruno by your side, testing OAuth APIs is less of a chore and more of a walk in the park. Just don’t forget the treats (a.k.a. access tokens)! 🐾
